signature: Nicola Hayes, Dementia Service Improvement Lead - Acute & Non Acute, PCOP, WHSCT
body:
Dear RoseJ22  
My name is Nicola Hayes and I am temporarily Acting Head of Service for Older People's Mental Health. My substantive post is Dementia Service Improvement Lead for Acute Hospitals.  
Thank you for sharing the positive experience that you and your mother had of your journey through the Day Procedure Unit in Altnagelvin.  
I hope that your mother's cataract procedure was successful and I am glad to hear that she is recovering well.  
Coming into the Day Procedure Unit can be a fearful and stressful time for any of us, never mind for someone living with dementia.  
The care and treatment provided is essential to ensure that any hospital journey is person centred particularly in your mother's case where this procedure may have been difficult for her.  
Approach and communication are vital in the caring profession, not only to ensure that your mother’s needs were met, but also that your needs were met.  
Your feedback is very welcome to ensure safe, effective, compassionate and well led care is delivered.  
Best Wishes  
Nicola

signature: Nicola Hayes, Dementia Service Improvement Lead - Acute & Non Acute, PCOP, WHSCT
body:
Hello NICI  
My name is Nicola Hayes and I am temporarily Acting Head of Service for Older People's Mental Health. My substantive post is Dementia Service Improvement Lead for Acute Hospitals.  
I am sorry to hear that your father has sadly passed away and my thoughts are with you at this time.  
Thank you for your feedback story.  
Community Care Services are vital, particularly for people living with dementia, to ensure continuity of care is maintained in their home environment, without any distressing and unnecessary transfers to hospital.  
Person centred care is paramount within dementia care and this has been evidenced throughout your experience. Approach and communication are vital in the caring profession, not only to ensure that all your father’s needs were met, but also that your needs were met during your difficult situation at that time.  
End of life care can be complex and can involve a number of different professionals across one or more services. I am equally delighted to hear that the care and treatment provided was of high standard throughout, compassionate, empathetic and person centred for both you and your father, during this critical aspect of care delivery for someone living with dementia.  
May I thank you for taking the time to share your experiences with us on care opinion.  
Your feedback is very welcome to ensure safe, effective, compassionate and well led care is delivered.  
Best Wishes  
Nicola

body:
Hi, thank you for getting back. I have got in touch with Jennifer.  
As I have highlighted, within the letter was a copy of blood results. The general person will not understand what they mean. This was up to me to make sense of and understand what was naming me as higher risk. It seriously needs to be explained.  
Part of the blood results was Papp-a being low. When you look into this it gives risks of premature birth, pre-eclampsia and stillbirth. This should not be up to the woman receiving this letter to understand and cause further anxiety.  
I can only hope that practice can change as a result of this feedback.
I have nothing but praise and THANKS for every person I saw. Courteous, professional but CARING ❤

signature: Lise Axford, Chief of Nursing, University Hospital Hairmyres, NHS Lanarkshire
body:
Dear Cat66  
Thank you for taking the time to share your experience. I am sorry that you had such a negative experience and that you felt communication was poor.  
I understand staff spent some time with you and again apologise if you were made to feel bad for complaining. Utilising treatment rooms is far from ideal and I fully understand and appreciate the concerns that you have raised. As you will be aware NHSL Lanarkshire is under exceptional pressure and we have had to take the very difficult decision to utilise treatment rooms for in patient care. This decision is made to create capacity in the emergency department for assessment of patients.  
I would have expected a full discussion prior to transfer and explanation of decision making so that you were fully informed and involved in this. Your care should not have been compromised in any way and I will raise with the team all the issues that you have raised. Your comments and feedback is very important to us and again I would like to offer my sincere apologies for the distress this has caused.  
I hope that you are recovering well and thank you for sharing your concerns  
Kind regards  
Lise

body:
While I accept that Ms Donaldson is trying to be helpful, sadly, for someone who has been waiting since mid June for results of a Cardiocall and Electrocardiogram and since late June for results of an Echocardiogram, the inability to make contact with anyone who is willing to help in the Cardiology Department is, I feel, a sad indictment of our NHS.  
I was told again today, when trying to make contact with the Cardiology Department, that it is completely possible that the Cardiologist associated with my case does not speak to people on the telephone. I do understand that the NHS is burdened with patient care but, seven weeks (so far - with no end in sight) to obtain results of tests that are important to me and no explanation as to why it should take so long apart from the fact that 'we are very busy' and 'I expect that they are being typed up'.  
I have left messages requesting that Ms Donaldson could call me back but so far this has not happened.

Dear DaE22,  
I am sorry that you have perceived a lack of mental health care. Without the clients name is it difficult to view what has happened and the decision making around this.  
Ealing Acton MINT offers client’s out patient appointments with Dr’s and other appointments with various professionals. Usually people do not see Dr’s as regularly as monthly. GP’s continue usually continue with prescribing outside of the clinics.  
Outside of appointment times, the Ealing MINT team has unplanned contact which used to be called a Duty service. Anyone open to Ealing Acton MINT can access this – although it is not an emergency service and you will usually have to wait.  
Long term use of diazepam is not usually recommended as it is highly addictive.  
If you have any further concerns, please contact our pals team by writing to pals@westlondon.nhs.uk or telephone 0800 064 3330.  
Avenue House Team

signature: Kirsten Dickson, Quality Improvement and Assurance Facilitator, Quality Improvement and Assurance Team, NHS Grampian
body:
Dear Braeside Resident,  
You and your family have had quite a worrying time, but it's comforting to hear your journey to receiving the appropriate investigations and care went as it should have and that you are on the road to recovery.  
Although there are lots of positive messages in your feedback - which are lovely to read - I noticed you were concerned about the ease of accessing the GP. Most of the GP Practices in Grampian are independent contractors and each practice makes it's own decisions about the ways patients access the services they provide. The GP practices are not currently registered to respond to feedback through the Care Opinion system and don’t routinely access the feedback received shared, but I'd be happy to share your story with them. If you'd like me to do that, you'd need to share the name of the practice you visited with me. If you'd feel comfortable doing so, you can contact me on email:kirsten.dickson@nhs.scot or phone / text: 07885720267.  
Take care,  
Kirsten

They can be contacted by email to bartshealth.familycontact@nhs.net or by telephoning 020 3594 2040.  We look forward to hearing from you; in the meantime, we will be sharing your feedback with the service.

Central Complaints Team

Dear Anonymous,

Thank you for your feedback. Unfortunately we do have a high call volume at 0800 in the morning but we do pool staff to ensure that call times are reduced. 
However we did make changes to the appointment system that were implemented from the 4th July 2022. The changes involved have given more varied access to our appointments which was advertised on our social media platforms as well on our website. Patients can now pre book more appointments through patient access, these include same day appointments, appointments for 1 week and 2 weeks in advance. Also patients can pre book appointments through the phone system. 
However just to reiterate the appointments are a finite resource and we can only offer what is available.
Regards,
LH

We welcome all comments and feedback from our patients as this helps us to develop our services in the future.

Dear Sue, 
Thank you for your comments, our staff like to receive feedback on our services . I am glad your visit met with all your expectations and that your experience was very positive .We aim to provide the service to our patients that we would like to receive ourselves and its good to have feedback that we are achieving this.

Kind regards,

David Stokes
Imaging Services Manager

Thank you for taking the time to provide feedback regarding your husband's care received at North Manchester General Hospital. It is very reassuring that you found the clinical team working in the emergency department to be both very caring and responsive when your husband was very poorly and that his on-going care at Manchester Royal Infirmary in the Intensive Care Unit, you found the staff to be incredible. The clinical teams in both areas will be very pleased to read your feedback. Once again thank you for taking the time to share your experience and that your husband continues to feel better and has a good recovery following his surgery. Kind Regards, Patient Experience Team.

Dear Brendan,

Firstly, thank you for taking the time to comment on the Practice, I appreciate that you have given us the chance to reflect on the problems you have faced with us.

To discuss our appointment system structure as a whole, we are aware that there have been difficulties over the past and present. Highlighting these issues and resolving them will involve considering various different obstacles we face as a GP surgery in the NHS today. Firstly, you have mentioned that the problems we face are not to do with funding, which I appreciate. However, the challenge we acknowledge is the ability to provide a service adequate for our vast population of 24,000 people. We are aiming to tackle this initial obstacle by recruiting GP registrars to help with the overwhelming pressures we face. We have a collection of 7 GP registrars who start with us this week, and we hope that this will show relief in our appointment structure.

I also appreciate that you have mentioned various other methods of managing an appointment structure to help meet the needs of our patients who do not fit into the standard 8 am rush for appointments.
Adapting to these conditions is essential for us to aim to become a better Practice. There have been times in the past we have trialed process' like this, e.g. releasing afternoon appointments at 11 am meaning there are two different times of the day for patients to book in to see us. This unfortunately did not work well at the time, however, we are still considering alternate methods of managing the structure which will be brought to our next appointments management meeting.

Your latter suggestion is about having a message on our telephone line stating the time of day we book appointments. Unfortunately, this is not something that we can openly advertise before speaking to a Patient, as we cannot discourage anyone from getting through to us, in case they are experiencing an emergency, or have an issue that can be resolved with a different method from our Reception team. 

To summarise, I do appreciate the points that you have made; they have been noted and will be discussed more within the Practice.
I hope this information has been helpful, and I would be happy to discuss this in more detail, should you request via complaints.deepingspractice@nhs.net

Kind regards
Joey Attwell
The Deepings Practice

Thank you for your comments. I am truly sorry that your experience wasn't satisfactory with the Practice. We are trying our hardest to meet the needs of all of our 7500 patient population and presently the 8am distribution of appointments model is the one that we are having to use due to the complexity of the situation that we still find ourselves in post covid. I am honestly trying to come up with a solution that meets everyone's needs as I am a patient myself and experience the same frustrations that you do. In September we will have more GP's on staff in order to be able to allow us to offer a wider range of appointments, I appreciate that this doesn't help your situation at this present time but I need you to know that the GP's and staff at Park House work extremely hard, in very challenging circumstances, to try and help as many patients as possible. I am sorry this reply is so tardy, I have been absent from work following an accident. 

If you would like to discuss this further please email me at nicola.raby2@knowsleyccg.nhs.uk or you may be interested in joining our Patient Participation Group - please contact the Surgery and ask to speak to Christina to join the group as this is a way to help make tangible change for the good of the patient population. Many thanks for the feedback, N Raby. Practice Manager

Dear Patient

I am truly sorry that you have had less than satisfactory service from the Practice. 

 I can assure you that there are doctors working at the Practice, we are a little thin on the ground due to it being holiday season but nontheless this is unacceptable. 
Please email me at nicola.raby2@knowsleyccg.nhs.uk and let me resolve this for you.
Thank you for bringing it to my attention.
Nicola Raby, Practice Manager

Heather

Thank you for your review. I am sorry you were disappointed with your recent consultation and I would encourage you to contact the practice so we can discuss.

To give a little bit of context, as with most GP practices across the UK we employ a variety of skilled and qualified clinical and non-clinical staff. 
We are actively seeking new opportunities to increase and broaden our current team in line with current Government and NHS directives.

Our Emergency Care Practitioners (ECP), one of whom you saw, are fully qualified clinicians with years of experience, including the ability to prescribe medication. We try to ensure that patients understand who it is they will be seeing when we offer them an appointment, we are sorry if this information was not communicated more clearly before your appointment.

Please be assured that we do have 6 doctors working at the practice, and we are actively recruiting another.

We would not advise calling 999 for anything other than in a true emergency.

Thank you for taking the time to review the surgery and please contact the practice should you wish to discuss this directly.

Castle Donington Surgery

Hi,

I am sorry to hear that your daughter-in-law did not receive the care you expected.

It is critical that any feedback requiring medical action be sent directly to the practice so that we can assess your situation and respond appropriately. Please contact me at the practice number so that we can discuss this further.

Thank You
Halima 
Yorkshire Street Surgery
